Highest grade ‘80s/early ‘90s post-punk weirdness from Stano, reaping highlights of his five LPs in a necessary retrospective - highly recommended to fans of his collaborators Michael O’Shea and Roger Doyle, and even Planxty and My Bloody Valentine, who both contribute…

description: The other week we dreamt that we asked Jonnine aka Jonnine Standish of f#cking HTRK to make some music for a tape series. She ended up sending us what was essentially a 9 track album of new songs featuring Jonnine on bass guitar, a Mopho synth, a wave drum and an electric wind instrument, plus her vocals, clicks and garden chimes, and... more

Theatric incantations from a new LA artist to the ambient chamber-pop sphere, patently inspired by synaesthesia and fantasy soundtracks

“Spells is the debut release by Los Angeles based multi-instrumentalist and composer Nailah Hunter on Leaving Records. Each of the EP’s six tracks represent a spell, a unique sonic place forged by imagination and... more

title_full:
Mark Leckey

              —

              (Boomkat Editions | Documenting Sound)
label: Boomkat Editions | Documenting Sound
description: It’s a proper madness this one, a fantasy travelogue stitching home recordings, spoken word and dismantled tunes like some hallucinogenic mixtape; part audio diary, part YouTube session taking in fairytale folk musics, iMessage notifications and gothic horror that will make you question... stuff. It's the sound of Mark Leckey at home on May 19th 2020, and it’s... more

title_full:
Cindy Lee

              —
              What's Tonight To Eternity
            
              (W.25TH / Superior Viaduct)
label: W.25TH / Superior Viaduct
description:
Very strong slab of haunted ‘60s pop themes and keeling synth noise from Canada’s Pat Flegel aka Cindy Lee, formerly of Canadian indie-pop heroes Women, now sounding like a spell concocted by Panda Bear, Forest Swords, Johnny Jewel and Dean Hurley’s Trouble. Check the samples and trust your ears, it’s a bewt!

“For Patrick Flegel, Cindy Lee is more... more

Ana Roxanne

              —
              Because of a Flower
            
              (Kranky)
label: Kranky
description:
Ana Roxanne follows up the short-and-sweet "~~~" with this devastatingly beautiful full-length for Kranky, joining the dots between the label's past and present with heartbreaking sounds that remind us of Labradford, Windy & Carl, Grouper and beyond.

The album was written over the last five years, when the LA-based, Oakland-raised artist released that debut... more

label: Hyperdub
description:
Avant R&B star Mhysa follows her acclaimed debut ‘fantasii’ - one of the definitive underground albums of 2017 - with its sister side, ‘Neveah’ for Hyperdub; a sprawling mosaic of raw, introspective R&B ballads, including a haunting take on a Nas classic in ‘breaker of chains’.

Lucrecia Dalt is back on RVNG with a complex and syrupy full-length of undulating rhythms and half-heard melodies, cracking with ASMR vocal elements and shrouded, mystical instrumentation.

At this stage, Dalt has successfully built herself a unique sound-world; 2018's "Anticlines" was inspired by her own work as a geotechnical engineer, and with "No Era... more

title_full:
Container

              —
              Scramblers
            
              (Alter)
label: Alter
description:
10 years since his debut, Container holds his line of bolshy, distorted machine rhythms for Alter.

Bringing his studio recordings closer than ever to the sound of his cultishly praised live shows, ‘Scramblers’ is as much mucky fun as the nippy motorbikes it’s named after. With the possible addition of some new software or bit of kit that gives this record a really... more

              (WORLD MUSIC)
label: WORLD MUSIC
description:
Dean Blunt’s World Music keeps us guessing with bar italia’s debut batch of lo-fi arabesques. If you know who's behind this one, holler.

Depending on what forum thread your checking, bar italia may be an as-yet-uncredited Blunt work, some new Mica Levi project or possibly something by the likes of Brynje’s Asger Hartvig (MC Boli), but naming games aside, it’s... more
